desc: The CARM1 gene encodes a methyltransferase protein that modifies arginines seventeen and 26 of histones and other proteins. CARM1 is recruited, along with EP300 and the NCOA-family of histone acetyltransferases, to active gene promoters, playing a role in transcriptional activation via chromatin remodeling (PMID: 16497732, 19405910). CARM1 is a positive regulator of Wnt/β-catenin expression, induces growth and proliferation in colon cancer cells (PMID: 21478268), and synergistically co-activates NF-kB pathway with EP300 in fibroblasts (PMID: 15616592). CARM1 is amplified in a small subset of cancers, such as neuroendocrine, prostate and ovarian tumors (cBioPortal, MSKCC, Nov 2016).
articles/0/title: Arginine methyltransferase CARM1 is a promoter-specific regulator of NF-kappaB-dependent gene expression.
articles/1/title: Kinetic analysis of human protein arginine N-methyltransferase 2: formation of monomethyl- and asymmetric dimethyl-arginine residues on histone H4.
articles/2/title: A coactivator role of CARM1 in the dysregulation of β-catenin activity in colorectal cancer cell growth and gene expression.
articles/3/title: Coactivator-associated arginine methyltransferase-1 enhances nuclear factor-kappaB-mediated gene transcription through methylation of histone H3 at arginine 17.

desc: CARM1, an epigenetic modifier and transcriptional activator, is altered by amplification in a small proportion of cancers.
